reply_context.text: we have reasons to ask these questions because we are embodied. we exist in the physical world and interact with it. we have physical and psychological needs that drive us to find new and better ways of doing things or explaining new and strange things we encounter.

There are (I think) two core assumptions baked into my position here. If you disagree with my position, you probably disagree with at least one of these assumptions:

1. The domain of possible knowledge is not finite (but is bounded).
2. Pursuit of knowledge is a motivated task.

reply_context.text: The problem, as you've pointed out, isn't automation so much as capitalism. reply_context.text:
You're continuing to misunderstand me. It's not that craving knowledge "gets you anything". It's that passion differentiates professional researchers from hobbyists.

If a lab has resources to allocate, they want those to go to people who are focused on that topic, not people who side project it.

posts.text:
You're continuing to misunderstand me. It's not that craving knowledge "gets you anything". It's that passion differentiates professional researchers from hobbyists.

If a lab has resources to allocate, they want those to go to people who are focused on that topic, not people who side project it.

reply_context.text: The idea that just the craving for knowledge would get you anything, is already very far from reality thanks to capitalism. It's a good starting point, and in my opinion a necessity to have in science. In a time where human research is considered a nice little side hobby, this won't be any better.

posts.text: Even if AI surpasses human efficiency to answer any question, humans will still be the ones asking them.

reply_context.text: I've spent nearly the last two decades working as a researcher for hire. Nearly every project, the most important and challenging work is framing the question correctly. This will always be a human endeavor, because passion is human. We have needs that demand satisfaction, and one such is curiosity.

posts.text: I've spent nearly the last two decades working as a researcher for hire. Nearly every project, the most important and challenging work is framing the question correctly. This will always be a human endeavor, because passion is human. We have needs that demand satisfaction, and one such is curiosity.

reply_context.text: Questions arise from experience, from encountering the unexpected or obstacles to be surmounted. AI only even have reason to be curious when we give them those reasons. There will always be a human at the top who owns the question or problem that gives the AI reason to investigate at all.
